keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon broke during a journey in September, resulting in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries.
The cable failed to meet the specifications set by the operator CARRIS and was not certified to carry passengers.

Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) indicate serious failures in the cable, maintenance practices, and brake systems.
Maintenance tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as 'compliant and accepted' by the operator.
Eyewitnesses described the descent of the funicular car as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man named Bruno describing it as 'a toy being thrown from one side of the Glória pavement to the other.'
The interim report is preliminary and not conclusive; a final report is expected to be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, killed at least 16 people and injured several others after a steel cable snapped. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) indicate that the cable failed to meet CARRIS's operational specifications and was not certified for passenger use. The investigation also found serious lapses in maintenance practices, including false documentation of completed tasks and a misleadingly compliant maintenance plan. Eyewitnesses described the descent as chaotic and uncontrollable, with one man named Bruno comparing it to a toy being thrown across the street. While the interim findings are preliminary, a final report is expected to be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
